title: Before 1 January 2022, will there be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States either in Iran or at sea?
preds:
The Iranians are proving that if Fidel outlived the American blockade for 50 years and 30 assesination attemps, they can too. Moreover, it seems that there is not even a chance that risking desabilizaing an area as conflictive driven as the middle east.
The Saudis were tinkering with the idea of intervention in Iran, the US did not fall for it, they got Israeli attention but not traction withou the US buy-in, how it will look in the open market of ideas and social disruption a collaboration of KSA  and Israel attacking Iran?

I am going to tweak my forecast down from 2% to 1% likely simply due to the diminishing window of time for this question. It was a low probability anyway but looking less and less likely at this point except purely in the case of absolute accident.
I'm going to take the plunge... 100% committed to this outcome.

A confrontation with Iran is likely in the next year, but not necessarily directly with the US.  US diplomacy has been very overt (re: Soleimani EKIA) regarding future US response being in-defense of US personnel in the MIddle East.  The  max pressure campaign has exhausted economic levers of power.  Diplomatically, removal from JICPOA can be discussed, and there are no agreements in-place to cease Iran from enriching their nuclear program.  We could argue the validity of JCPOA as it was set to expire However, NPR reported on 28 Nov 2021 the intent to restart diplomatic engagement going forward.  https://www.npr.org/2021/11/28/1058533008/iran-nuclear-deal-talks-us I also think it's safe to say the likelihood of an overt US hostile action is unlikely.   However, I would not be surprised to see Israel respond overtly as a nuclear capable Iran is an existential threat.

Iranian News agencies are reporting that Iranian leaders are intent on getting sanctions against Iran lifted.  The desire for reduction in sanctions coupled with a peaceful resolution of the Vietnamese tanker being released from Iranian custody all point to a reduced liklihood of lethal confrontation between Iran and the US.
While there is still the possibility for an accident, with the time horizon diminishing for this question, the probability of an incident is less. Lowering my forecast from 15% to 2%.
There is no indication that there will be military action, so I hold on to my prediction.

There's little appetite for a confrontation from the Biden administration. Iran would have to take very aggressive steps to undermine regional stability - Iran is not an irrational actor so that seems unlikely as long as Biden administration is sitll working on its roadmap for Iran. Besides, tensions are somehow abating between Iran and Saudi Arabia.

As Us looks to get back into an agreement with Iran for mitigation of their nuclear program both countries seem to be attempting to cool things off.  Sanctions were levied against members of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corps for actions in support of insurgent groups in Iraq, Lebanon, and Yemen. This was not widely publicized which indicates to me that the administration is trying to hold Iran accountable but not publicly poke them in the eye.  Bottom line: Biden admin definitely wants to get back to JCPOA and Iran wants out from under sanctions to revitalize the economy so in the short term I think relations will be stable.  There is always a chance for mistakes but I thnk both sides are being careful and will continue to be so until the next phase in relationship reveals itself.

For the past year except September 2021 there has been at least one incident involving Iran.  Thus far there has been no lethal activity between the US and Iran but with the sheer number of incidents and Iran's regular use of UAS and other kinetic delivery means the chance exists, albeit low for some form of lethal confrontation.

Military force pivoting to INDO-PACOM region.  NSS interim change discusses Iran volatility but does not cross threshold for strategic competition yet.  Regional tensions appear to subside compared to Solomeni strike over 1-year ago.
Reviewed other forecasters'  comments and changed to 1 chance in 20.  Agree with IR motivation to renter JPCOA.
Lethal confrontations between the US and Iranian forces are rare in the previous two decades.  The Iranian regime does not want to antagonize the Biden administration from reentering the JCPOA.
Iran is still seeking for the US to return to the JCPOA. This becomes less likely the more they confront US allies at sea. For the next few months they will be on their best behavior.
It's more likely that a Lethal confrontation will occur between Iran and Israel than between Iran and the US.

I do not think that anyone wants to turn over the honey pot at this point. Biden renews offer to 'return to full' nuclear deal 'if Iran does the same https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/world/biden-renews-offer-to-return-to-full-nuclear-deal-if-iran-does-the-same-7492501.html

4%
Yes
Factors Decreasing Probability: 
- Both Iran and the US have national interests at stake if stalled negotiations terminate. 
- Iran wants sanctions lifted. 
- Biden administration has a strong desire to return to JCPOA. 
- Sentiment of US institutions and actors is to avoid lethal force against Iran's military personal. 
- Pattern of behavior, Iran uses asymmetric means of attack to avoid ties to Iran military killing US military force. 
- Pattern of behavior, Iran military attacks non-military targets. Factors elevating probability: 
- Iran production of nuclear material is increasing (Natanz facility enriching small amounts of nuclear fuel at bomb-grade material, turning uranium to metallic form) 
- Iran has been increasingly aggressive at attacking non-military targets within the Middle East. Iran could inadvertently kill a US service member during a feature attack at sea. 
- Iran revenge for Solemani's death causes need to push materials across sea to attack locations that US military personnel intercept.

I agree with @rjlb0204, the incentives for both sides are against confrontation.  Accidents and miscalculations happen, but over the time horizon of roughly 3 months, I think there is an extremely low probability.

Iran's Raisi is more focused on curbing COVID issues and other internal issues.  Conversely, the economy and inflation is a significant concern and sanctions have constrained their economy.  Publicly he stated he will pursue diplomacy; however, he is a considered hard-liner conservatism, and there is internal tension with reformists seeking modernization.  He could use a confrontation with the U.S. to galvanize domestic sentiment to align his agenda.

Factors Decreasing Probability:
- Both Iran and the US have national interests at stake if stalled negotiations terminate.
- Iran wants sanctions lifted.
- Biden administration has a strong desire to return to JCPOA.
- Sentiment of US institutions and actors is to avoid lethal force against Iran's military personal.
- Pattern of behavior, Iran uses asymmetric means of attack to avoid ties to Iran military killing US military force. 
- Pattern of behavior, Iran military attacks non-military targets.     Factors elevating probability:
- Iran production of nuclear material is increasing (Natanz facility enriching small amounts of nuclear fuel at bomb-grade material, turning uranium to metallic form)
- Iran has been increasingly aggressive at attacking non-military targets within the Middle East. Iran could inadvertently kill a US service member during a feature attack at sea.
- Iran revenge for Solemani's death causes need to push materials across sea to attack locations that US military personnel intercept.

https://www.cfr.org/global-conflict-tracker/conflict/confrontation-between-united-states-and-iran
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93United_States_relations
There have been 0 lethal confrontations in Iran or at sea since 1980 but tensions are high.

I'm going with 5% simply because the current governments are generally looking to revamp/reset the JCPOA, from which stirring up confrontation at sea would detract. The idea of either deliberately launching provocations seems unlikely, though accidents can and do happen.

Key considerations for probability are whether or not the regime follows the rational actor model, whether nuclear capability fuels Iran’s proxy ambitions, timeline for US withdrawal from Iraq, how much control Iran has over its Quds forces in the field, perceived political will for a US retaliation for a nuclear or non-nuclear Iran, and potential for inadvertent confrontation. These variables, unfortunately, aggregate to a 7% probability.

Tensions are still relatively high between the US and Iran after the Qassem Soleimani killing. In addition, there are frequent encounters between US Navy vessels and Iranian small boats in the Persian Gulf that are often very close interactions and include the firing of warning shots by the US Navy. With the increased tension hanging over the relationship, there is a measure of risk of a confrontation occurring between the US and Iran brought on by a simple accident during one of these maritime encounters. However, that risk is tempered by the current presidential administration's desire to reduce US military involvement overseas and by the relatively close time horizon of the question.

Lowering for passage of time.  There's not a whole lot out there right now to lead me to believe Iran is planning anything.  Always a chance for an accidental encounter.  For a review of some of the latest activities (including over the last two years) https://www.cfr.org/timeline/us-relations-iran-1953-2021
The lack of US response to Iranian actions leads me to believe we're not actually serious about a "maximum pressure campaign" anymore.
Interesting that this didn't change much with the ongoing proxy attacks in Syria.  Will be interesting to see if Iran wants to take this to a wider theater.
Not seen or heard anything to change my current views
Adjusting for passed time and Biden being pro-Iran
With JCPOA talks ongoing in Vienna not plausible.
Lots of posturing always going on, and Biden is seen rightly as weak. Could happen.
Looking less likely as time moves on. Adjusting forecast.
While all eyes are on Israel and Hamas, this doesn't discount an accidental lethal encounter.  Maintaining at 8%
maintaining current forecast. If the Gaza conflict continues there may be cause for confrontation but at this point it isn't in the best interest of Iran to initiate engagement.
Dropping with a quieter month following the recent sabre rattling (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1269825).
maintaining current forecast. Current activity seems to be more politically motivated than actual intent on confrontation. No expectation that it will be lethal.
Not lethal, but is this Iran testing US, or some posturing ahead of agreement on JCPOA? - https://bit.ly/3tDpjJW

Increasing likelihood as they play games of Chicken.  I do not foresee a planned confrontation, but it does not mean it won’t happen. I assume for this purposes an accident between the two counts.  https://www.politico.com/news/2021/05/10/us-ship-encounter-iranian-boats-486637
With the nuclear deal on the table, no side is interested in amping up tensions unless discussions go sideways. If something happens, expect it to be subdued for the time being.

Escalation of Naval action in the Persian Gulf requires a review of this one [1 and 2]. Warning shots fired (in night time conditions), Iranian speed boats conducting "swarming" harassment activity.  Reportedly the first time such activity has taken place in over a year. Whilst the images are powerful this seems to be muscle flexing from the Iranian side more than anything else (likely as the "opening salvo" of hand strengthening 
for negotiations with the US on resumption of the Nuclear deal and as a show of strength for their own people at a time of manifest fragility), but in a tinderbox environment it wouldn't take more than a single wild card Captain (on either side arguably) to set the spark and see this escalate into a (likely small scale) lethal engagement: a skiff being sunk in a collision or a warning shot becoming more than just a warning in the darkness and fog of war. Upping the forecast due to escalating proximity and frequency of action and the apparent willingness of the Iranian side to show their teeth to the new US administration rather than build bridges.  Disappointing, counter-productive but not entirely unexpected. WILL appears to be in place on both sides to challenge each others positions through military posturing (although not, at a policy level, anything more kinetic than that at this stage).
CAPABILITY is clearly in place on both sides to cause some form of lethal harm.
OPPORTUNITY appears to be increasing with the escalation in movements, forces and "near miss" engagements of this sort. Still feels like it remains far more likely that, if it happens, the Iranians will "go live" through more asymmetric means (and outside Iran's national military and territory) or against civil shipping and private maritime security during some form of trade embargo operation (with estimates on how long Iran could realistically "close" the straits of Hormuz ranging from a few days to 100 days [3]) . So, the most credible routes to lethal engagement between national forces of the US and Iran still seems far more likely to be a miscalculation, misinterpretation or a moment of chaotic "rule of engagement" interpretation. Despite the hot rhetoric lethal engagements between US and Iranian forces are, based on a historical baseline, incredibly rare (with the last "shots fired" between US and Iranian military forces being the Trump administration's Drone Strike on Qasem Soleimani on 3 Jan 2020 [4], and even that would have fallen out of scope for this question given that it took place within Iraq's borders). With malign actors (both in the US homeland and abroad) looking at a military confrontation between the US and Iran as an agenda opportunity however...Will drop back down to crowd base rate if things cool off and this recent activity proves to be a "spat". [1]  https://www.forbes.com/sites/joewalsh/2021/04/27/us-navy-ship-fired-warning-shots-at-iranian-boats-after-close-encounter/
[2]  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zCorSqB-UQw
[2]  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=alkhi0jouFE
[3]  https://direct.mit.edu/isec/article/33/1/82/11939/Closing-Time-Assessing-the-Iranian-Threat-to-the
[4]  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Qasem_Soleimani
A lot of factors at play for this one.  I don't see Biden wanting a fight with Iran.  So with, perhaps the occasional skirmish, I don't see anything of import occurring.
Maintaining at 10% to account for accidental lethal encounters.
I don't see confrontation as part of the US strategy at the moment. maintaining current forecast.

The Biden administration seems more conciliatory to Iran, looking to rejoin the JCPOA, if Iran takes the first steps to reducing its nuclear ambitions. The US and allies continue to exercise in the Persian Gulf, heightening tensions.  Additionally, the US may not like China’s intentions to play mediator in an effort to lead de escalation and a return to stability in the region.
https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/202103/1219537.shtml
I think Biden is much more pro-Iran than the previous administration. Adjusting on reports that Iran interfered in US politics supporting Biden.
Absolutely no change in the geostrategic situation since my last prediction. Therefore the probability shall remain at 5%.
Tweaking down a bit as not seeing much activity in the area.

There is continuous action between the US and Iran as proxies, and through different countries (like Syria).  
A lethal engagement at sea is most likely, but would probably be accidental. 
List of US/Iran engagements (2019-2021):  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019%E2%80%932021_Persian_Gulf_crisis#January_2021
Tweaking down due to change in area situation.
I'm moving this up a bit as I believe that the area in question may begin to heat up.
Always a chance it could happen, but the likelihood is very slim. Posturing will occur, but it is unlikely a lethal confrontation will occur.
if Iran want to make trouble it will be at a US ally rather then directly
Not the United States. “Building Partner Capacity” BPC. This was one of General Demsey’s primary goals as CJCS. Plus the Persian Navy not equipped for naval battle.
Would the US initiate such confrontation intentionally ?  Highly unlikely.  Would Iran?  very small possibility.  Accidentally player, Iraq, India, China, Russia, other?

Despite increased aggression from Iran in recent years against the United States and especially our key ally, Israel, the new administration has pre-emptively announced and promoted a policy of de-escalation and/or appeasement via the proposed reinstatement of the US-Iran Nuclear Deal which is viewed by many to be a measure for peace in the region. However, the Trump administration has also imposed many punitive tariffs on Iran for their human rights abuses and state-sponsoring of terrorism, but Biden has not signified whether or not he plans to lift these sanctions [1]. Even so, if negotiations were to proceed with Iran, Iran would likely nonetheless attempt to use the lifting of the sanctions as one of their demands due to the immense economic damage these sanctions have caused --  a demand which Biden would likely concede to in an effort to maintain the success of his peace initiative [2]. Therefore, I conclude that the risk of war with Iran is minimal, although present by virtue of their government's aggression and hostile attitude towards America and its allies. [1] https://nypost.com/2020/12/02/biden-says-hell-try-to-return-to-iran-deal-keep-china-deal/ [2] https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-48119109

Both Iran and US want to move forward. We want them not to have nukes, which the previous administration made more likely. They want sanctions relief, which they may get, but not in the first year of Biden's presidency.
Staying aligned to the crowd with probability tracking very low. Original rationale linked below. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1220808
What’s interesting is... is who wants it. Not the US military. Not the normal citizens of Iran. Not the American people. Not the Iranian military. What’s this really about? Stupid stuff.

Down 1% for crowd alignment only.  There are potential scenarios for an accidental / locally induced lethal engagement (see previous post: likely in contested waters) but the probabilities in timeframe feel incredibly low. Original rationale linked below. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1220808
Depends how initial interaction between new US administration and Iran starts out.
They dont Stop building freedom in iraque and syria and they want a nuclear Weapon also Iran gets help from China Russia and Pakistan ...

The US - Iran conflict is gaining tension, however, it may be possible for the US to hold the conflict during COVID-19 (not because of the virus but during it). I think we would likely see the tension come to a head and interact more in 2022.
Accidentally maybe, but there is nothing to gain in engaging in a confrontation.

Very unlikely. Iran will do it's best to try to build up it's leverage before everyone has to return to the table to re-ignite the nuclear deal. This could cause some problems in the region and pressures - esp as Israel may continue to use the opportunity to disrupt. However Iran knows the Biden Administration is likely to want to return to the table and offer stability that will lead to a stronger Iranian economy. It seems Israel is also aware of this so has conducted many actions as possible in the run up to the US inauguration.

The first year of a new Presidency is seen as a testing ground for external state actors and therefore Iran is likely to push its boundaries as much as possible.  Their erratic behavior and internal mismanagement can lead to a miscalculation or tactical problem wherein a warning shot’ for example could turn lethal.  In other words, there is high probability Iran will do something militarily against the US, but they will attempt to keep their kinetics non-lethal.

It's very unlikely that the Biden administration would go to war in its first year, but Iran has vowed to avenge Soleimani's death for a while, and they might have been tempted to do so in 2020, but might also have considered waiting for the Trump administration to go out. But following the same reasoning, they might not want to put the new administration under pressure so early, and they might just escalate their nuclear program or use other non-violent ways to confront the US on the international scene. To be revised
Biden will not be as provocative as Trump as he won't need to distract from home news policies in the same way that Trump bid.

Not before, but after 2022, maybe Spring, there will be confrontation between the national military forces of Iran and the United States. It is too soon for Biden to go into war. Corona and other matters will be first in line.
Got to start somewhere.  Given the assasination of a key Iranian scientist around the holidays, threats have been made to retailiate.

Outside View: Lethal events attributed to the US either in Iranian territory/airspace or at sea in the last 10 years are actually quite limited. There were assassinations of Iranian nuclear scientist in 2010-2012, and again in 2020, but these were not attributed to the US. The killing of Soleimani was in 2020 and included 10 dead, but this didn’t happen on Iranian soil/territory. There has been widespread attribution that many US deaths in Iraq and Afghanistan can be attributed to Iranians, but these did not occur in Iran or at sea. Based on my research, there are potentially 3-10 Americans detained by Iran at this time, but these people are not a part of the national military forces of the US. BL: based on how narrow the question is, I have been unable to find a specific case that would fit the question within the last 10 years.  Inside View: With the Biden administration taking over, there is talk of possibly returning to JCPOA, although this could be difficult. There is also talk that Iran may try to test Biden. Regardless, Biden is not taking as hard of a line on Iran as Trump did, and I view the probability that Iran would escalate with Biden in the next year as lower than if Trump were president.  Synthesis: it is 1/25/21, by 1/1/22 my estimate is that there is a 2% chance of a lethal event which meets all of the conditions outlined in the question.  Cheers.

Despite the Biden administration's indication that they are considering rejoining the JCPOA, Iran's recent tests of missiles and suicide drones as well as increased uranium enrichment in early January point to sustained tensions. In addition, their vow to avenge the death of their top nuclear scientist could embroil the US in the future. While Iran will likely continue to exert pressure, but remain cautious in the near-term, there is still the possibility for a confrontation to become lethal. With nearly a year to go on this question, I think that there's a 1 in 12 chance for a future confrontation in Iran or at sea to become lethal.
Would be unintended but a large chance due to recent history and confusion over US efforts to realign foreign policy post Trump

US administration change invalidates recent base rate considerations. While not yet publicly walking away from maximum pressure campaign, the new US administration has made every indication of reopening dialogue on JCPOA or negotiating new agreement to limit Iran's nuclear program. With key figures in new administration being principle drafters of the diplomatic approach of the JCPOA in the Obama administration it is likely the administration will attempt to minimize direct threats to Iran.
https://www.timesofisrael.com/violating-the-nuke-deal-iran-shows-it-wants-to-talk-to-biden/
https://www.jpost.com/opinion/the-new-biden-administration-may-change-the-situation-in-yemen-656133 Militia issues and potential action by Israel will continue to maintain tension and the threat for conflict which may continue to spiral over the course of the year. Particularly if Israel feels the new US administration does not share the same threat calculation of Iranian influence in Syria.
https://www.voanews.com/extremism-watch/experts-israel-likely-continue-attacking-iranian-targets-eastern-syria
https://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2021/01/20/Israeli-Syrian-officials-discussed-Iran-and-its-militias-presence-in-Syria-Report One flyer issue. If sanctions are not lifted or meaningful progress made to return parties to JCPOA, Iran may take steps to remove IAEA inspectors. Previous countries that have removed inspectors have had different world reaction - Iraq, Gulf War 1991, DPRK, 1993-2003 withdraw from NPT - setting a base rate of 50% for conflict and casualties due to a country restricting UN led nuclear weapons inspections as signatories of the Non-Proliferation Treaty.
https://www.niacouncil.org/news/iran-to-limit-nuclear-inspections/ Taking all factors into consideration I establish an initial probability of 1 occurrence over 10 opportunities.
Adjusting down 1% simply to stay aligned to the crowd with a 5% escalator at this early juncture.

Confrontation would not benefit any party. Iran is trying to get back to the JCPOA (or at least that's what its diplomats are saying [1][2], probably also struggling internally) and didn't make any significant move in the recent Trump-era tension in the area [2].  President Biden will be busy himself with issues at home (health, political and economic crisis) and abroad (mainly Russia and China, and complete build-up of relationship) to want to enter a new one. So, only ones interested would be KSA and Israel. Counting this and an accident or fatal mistake, the chances are very low. 

[1] https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/iran/2021-01-22/iran-wants-nuclear-deal-it-made
[2] https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2021/01/06/iran-bares-its-teeth-while-its-rivals-mend-fences
Initial projection. Not expecting a confrontation.
Adjusting down 1% simply to stay aligned to the crowd with a 5% escalator at this early juncture.
Biden was part of the Obama era nuclear agreement. Relatively dovish on Iran. No prominent hawks in the administration

The iranians now that a presidentially(?) President like Biden who listens to the "experts" would never authorize the assassination of someone who is part of the iranian elite. Therefore they will now act more brazenly. Wise experienced and empathic Biden would retaliate with an attack on civilians, not with an attack on a proud great general who even liked poetry.

As with 2020, I believe it unlikely. However, things change and Jan 2022 is a long time away. This is my opening bid to get me into the game, before reading any artefacts on the topic. 
Next step is to read up on the current situation and the influencing factors that can change the situation.
Hopefully now there are rational, reasonable and realistic politics in the US (again)

Very doubtful, Biden will move cautiously in the region, Tehran will as well. The dominant issue will be whether the US rejoins agreement before Iran downgrades its nuclear program or if Iran makes the first move as US would like.

Rather than retyping reasoning see:
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1220953
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1220912
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1220884
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1220929 And Ignoring Teenage troublemakers like Gavrilo Principe.

Isaac Asimov predicted the format for slow burn conflict in this century. I agree with many of  the posts here that say escalation will generally be avoided. We supplied weapons to Israel of course, for our economic benefit. The combination of lethal and separately, confrontation, on their own are open ended. As to how it will be treated, and the politics behind I'm not sure it means escalation or that we will receive good information. We assume the US is involved for truly democratic reasons (not sure personally) so perhaps trying to assess all motivations then reverse engineer. Assuming conflict will arise and then looking for what stands in the way of that is more how I'd like to look at it. Humans spend more money on fighting than any other collective issue and do we have reason to believe that will change yet? Honest questions I hope to gain more insight from the knowledgeable folks on this. Thanks.

The new Biden lead administration came into office yesterday. Biden has made it clear that his focus will be Covid, correcting the 'ills' of the previous administration, climate change policies and rejoining the Paris Club and JCPOA. Looking at Biden's history in office, it is unlikely he will seek confrontation directly or indirectly with Iran. It will, however, be interesting to see how Biden's foreign policy in MENA will either develop or stall the apparent smoothing of relations in the area achieved by the previous administration. More importantly, regarding Saudi Arabia's apparent desire to use the new relations with Israel and other GCC states, including Qutar, to control Iran.  From the Iranian perspective, any conflict with USA in Iranian airspace or territory would have to be a serious challenge to the country's sovereignty for them to react militarily as it is unlikely the Iranians have the firepower to survive, Even with support from Russia. Nonetheless, my current allocation of 1% is in light of the the possibility of an accident leading to some form of lethal, short conflict, most likely at sea in the Straits of Hormuz,  @Lestatbq Nice answer and reply to the comment from @Francis_Urquhart

Both sides, in my view, strongly wish to avoid confrontation during the first year of the Biden administration.  Iran wishes to claw back its lost gains from the JCPOA and will seek to exert maximum suasion on the Biden administration to re-enter the accord.   The Biden administration for its part is focused on the Covid pandemic and domestic challenges.  In terms of foreign policy priorities, the administration will want to focus on China, combating Russian malign influence in Europe, and managing the Southwestern Border of the U.S. and the sources of migrant flows from Central America.  The last thing they want is to start any sort of conflict in the Middle East.   That said, so-called "normal accidents" are real and escalations to lethal violence through mutual mis-perception or misunderstanding are common in the history of international politics.   For that reason, I think the crowd forecast of 2% is perhaps low.

Biden is interested in reducing tensions between the US and Iran and will do everything possible to make this happen. Additionally, it is unlikely that Iran will directly confront the United States militarily because that type of action will not allow them to accomplish their goals of having sanctions reduced/lifted [1]. Further, the Biden administration has stated that they intend to rejoin the JCPOA [2]. While that may not be feasible, due to the actions taken by the previous administration, it does show that the Biden administration is more interested in lowering tensions than increasing them. Further, the last conflict at sea that almost led to fatalities between Iran and the United States occurred in 2016 when 10 US sailors were captured. Iran did not execute any of those individuals as they, most likely, made the strategic decision that killing US military members would not further their ability to achieve their strategic goals [3]. Also, the last time Iran engaged US military aircraft was in 2019 when they shot down an unmanned drone [4]. The US has also engaged Iranian-backed Shia militants in Iraq, but since those actions occurred outside of Iran, their territorial waters/airspace, and not in international airspace over the sea (nor are those proxies Iranian military/LE) the engagements fall outside of the scope of this question [4]. Finally, President Biden's first year in office will, most likely, focus on domestic issues such as the COVID-19 pandemic, unemployment, and economic assistance to Americans who need it. If they make foreign policy a priority they will most likely focus on strengthening ties with European/NATO allies and rebuilding relationships with allies in the Asia-Pacific. A nuclear Iran is not something most Americans are currently concerned about so it would seem unlikely that the Biden Administration would put themselves in a situation that could lead to a lethal confrontation with Iran. Thus, I rate the probability of a lethal confrontation between the US and Iran before 1 Jan 2022 at a 0% probability. [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2021/01/19/biden-doesnt-need-rush-back-into-iran-nuclear-deal-defuse-tensions/
[2] https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/12/09/biden-foreign-policy-iran/
[3] https://www.propublica.org/article/trump-keeps-talking-about-last-military-standoff-iran-what-really-happened-farsi-island-navy
[4] https://www.forbes.com/sites/joewalsh/2021/01/01/heres-why-tensions-are-rising-between-iran-and-the-us/?sh=996b4f54585d
Based on the new president of the US.
Going low since the new administration is unlikely to do anything to escalate the situation.

Nobody, whether central or peripheral to this simmering feud, wants gunplay.  Accidents happen, but both teams have effective c&c systems and carefully crafted rules of engagement.  As the year wears on, I expect to go down from 2%.  (Full disclosure:  My expectations not infrequently turn out to be misguided. )

Several reasons why both sides will want to open doors and talks rather than open fire, but there are always possibilities (more likely before talks officially reopen on Iran Nuclear deal) that hard line elements in the Iranian government will try for a few tanker snatches in the gulf to gain some early leverage (a very deep seated Persian approach to negotiations: always have something to come to the table with) and offset the new sanctions imposed by #45 on his way out the door. A “tit for tat” tanker seizure was reported by Bloomberg on the 4th Jan 21 (https://www.bloombergquint.com/business/iran-says-it-has-seized-an-oil-tanker-in-persian-gulf) but this news was promptly swallowed up by events in the US.  This shows Iran is still keen to maintain an outwardly aggressive posture, and such things can easily escalate for numerous local and hard to control reasons (e.g. feisty low level military commanders with a Soleimani grudge). However, such past piracy actions have rarely spilt blood (the lethal part of this question): they are generally engineered as headline and hostage / leverage grabbers and to open talks rather than shut them down.  Any lethal action in ship seizures is also more likely to involve ship-borne private security than US national forces unless things get way out of control. Biden is very unlikely to continue Drumpf’s (https://twitter.com/RealDonalDrumpf?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor) drone assassination / engineered provocation programmes against Iranian leadership, although local / regional actors may attempt to stir the pot to drag the US into an engagement against their will (and to Iran’s ultimate disadvantage).  Rocket attacks against US military bases in neighbouring countries remains possible but such things have historically been part of a deliberate response to provocation (less likely now the Troll in Chief is out of the White House) and would not resolve the question anyway given the notable absence of US military bases "in Iran"! It’s also worth noting that Israel (who have done well out of the Trump administration) will likely not want to loose the initiative following the the change over of US leadership and will be driving for more stringent controls.  Hard line elements may seek to induce something violent / lethal / spectacular to force Biden’s hand in maintaining a hard line with Iran peace overtures.  Israels response to the Biden administration over the next year is one to watch (good summation of Biden / Israel relationship here: https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/views-on-israel-of-u-s-presidential-candidates-2020-joe-biden). TLDR: there are various routes to flashpoint lethal engagements within this questions geographical and physical bounds (maritime escalation, inducement and provocation by local regional actors, targeted (and likely limited) response to rocket attacks on regional US assets) that mean this cannot be called a 0% event.  But its also fair to say this is not in the strategic interests of either protagonist’s leadership at this moment, making the most likely routes to lethal engagement accidental or induced by external players and external interests (which usually come with some preemptive tells and flags to adjust forecasts from). Not impossible by any stretch, but unlikely in today’s conditions.

In Yemen, Syria and Iraq Iranian forces remain engaged in lethal conflicts. The USA also has commitments in those areas, and also to keeping shipping through the Gulf free of Iranian influence. A lethal confrontation is very likely - albeit the USA may characterize the actor as "Iranian" or "Iranian-backed" despite denials by Iran. There are many actors within the Iranian state who may also seek confrontation, some of whom have assets such as allied militia, who may also take initiative.

Iran has multiple reasons to mend fences.. 
or at least prevent further deterioration, while maintaining their place in the Middle East.. US has to balance US interests and the interests of allies... engagement with Iran after the Trump years will be an easy reset.. Neither has any real incentive to bloody the other's nose... currently, anyway..

This is a non-zero number. Biden wants the United States back in the Iran nuclear deal, but Biden also has a problem with Russia. Iran is a Russia proxy. My larger prediction is that Biden is going to start a war somewhere with a Russia proxy within 18 months, possibly Venezuela, Syria, or Eastern Europe. Especially as the economy continues to deteriorate and inflation rises, those Keynesians actually believe that war stimulates the economy and they certainly believe it takes our mind off of the economy. I will be quick to raise my prediction under the right circumstances
I think the likelihood is low, as Biden is in favor of reinstating the Iran deal and Iran wants that too. Both sides seem unlikely to escalate when they want cooperation from the other.
